An intern leaked half the private key for an encrypted message. Can you use the exposed bits to recover the full key and decrypt 3263530477193622642552536511464632810638659678022375941898857788549290733570926899773302108383910424047335884888521890555819429242740743871865224914667845?

The flag format is flag{...}
n=10490924739008610298566419833353034583174751294879629376635305587830438793592503283799306334838067190153522045489784084918661399326256918210298333145669907, e=10398884900853368606595292588046667011874676583573283409756462832647002160259715887186012376343456990740019035470326369832277439295775365830552873783441141, partial_p=16739570225738654742

---

## Challenge Technical Details
flag: flag{t3dbl47b}
cipher: RSA
ciphertext: 3263530477193622642552536511464632810638659678022375941898857788549290733570926899773302108383910424047335884888521890555819429242740743871865224914667845
vulnerability: partial key exposure
hint: A partial exposure of a prime number's bits can significantly weaken RSA security. Look into lattice-based techniques like Coppersmith's attack.
necessary_info: The flag format is flag{...}
n=10490924739008610298566419833353034583174751294879629376635305587830438793592503283799306334838067190153522045489784084918661399326256918210298333145669907, e=10398884900853368606595292588046667011874676583573283409756462832647002160259715887186012376343456990740019035470326369832277439295775365830552873783441141, partial_p=16739570225738654742
extra_info: p=105075985313611321142343765631861938629882940158608279993451224212249350890799, q=99841316811802839903196090135385892106574874797132280591231389108901458694493, Ï†(n)=10490924739008610298566419833353034583174751294879629376635305587830438793592298366497180920677021650297754797659047627103705658765672235596977182336084616
subtype: partial_key_exposure
